Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as a threat to freedom of speech.
The bill is compared to totalitarian regimes, suggesting it is undemocratic.
The legislation is viewed as a violation of human rights, specifically referencing Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Concerns about government overreach and potential abuse of power by unelected bureaucrats.
Notable Quotes: This disgraceful Bill ignores our obligations as signatory to Human Rights documents and is reminiscent of dictatorships such as North Korea and China.

Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states that 'Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers.'
It is not the role of the government to tell people what they can and cannot say or think.
